section.title: Second Conditional
section.sectiontitle: Use the Second Conditional to talk about unreal or imaginary situations in the present/future. Make the Second Conditional with if + Past Simple + would + verb.
section.text1a: If she had a car, she would drive to work.
section.text2a: If I became rich, I would buy an island.
section.sectiontitle2: We can put the if clause after the result clause.
section.text3a: If he stopped smoking, he would feel better.
section.text4a: He would feel better if he stopped smoking.

section.title: Second Conditional
section.sectiontitle: Use might + verb when the result is not certain.
section.text1a: If I had more money, I might start a company.
section.text2a: She might be quite good if she was an actress.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the First Conditional for real situations (if + Present Simple + will). Use the Second Conditional for unreal situations.
section.text3a: If you lend me $1, I'll buy a newspaper.
section.text4a: If you lent me $1,000,000, I'd buy a big house.
